w9gnGi-K1fy1hkeXTCgMBg.text: Food look fancy bit not really impressive. Yet the smell just lures you to go in and biy some.

9sqVB2idoshvJxAIdRY19Q.text: I am genuinely a fan of this place. I love their pots of two jams and one spreadable chocolate that they serve. I mean - if I want a whole dollop of condiments on my piece of fresh crusty baguette - I'd have that. They don't give you those small little jars that wouldn't even fit a teaspoon - they give you proper jars or sweet spreads!I mean..of course it's unhealthy - eating that much sugar, but if you're seeing a friend before they take off to mainland Europe from St Pancras, or it is yourself preparing your tummy for the amazing guilty food at France - I'd strongly recommend. Their coffee is great. That first sip in the morning was just unbelievable - I had goosebumps of how perfect my Americano was. They serve it in weird handless mugs - so that you can hold that bowl and warm your fingers up. My friend loved the cheesecake (can't judge on that - I couldn't have it!). But I did try their selection of nicely served sandwiches - and they were great.I would place this place outside the station - so that you could breath in the amazing London weather before you set off elsewhere. Otherwise - perfect.

OTfY65Sfzkew1x1Y_YDGsg.text: A very nice place for brunch. Healthy and fresh food. It is exactly what I wanted to find waiting for my train. The food came out quick and the servers were on top or it.

QzhIb49xk4gy3XVKHbF0FA.text: I was a little sad to waste a meal on our trip to Europe at a Le Pain Quotidien, seeing as I can stop by any time in L.A. and generally choose not to.  Still, had to eat before catching a train to Paris.The service wasn't blatantly bad, but it tended towards surly and inattentive.  This was especially obvious as the space isn't particularly large.  The set-up is comfortable and kind of cute, with light wooden tables stashed with sugar cubes and house-made jams and nut spreads.My mother and I ordered a Scottish smoked salmon and dill tartine and a granola parfait with organic yogurt and fresh fruit.  The tartine came on soft buttered whole wheat bread with nothing but a few sprigs of dill and a couple thin slices of radish to hide the fishiness.  I actually liked it, but I eat smoked salmon plain.  My mother got pretty desperate to kill the taste after one bite.  The parfait was mediocre.  There wasn't a lot of fruit and the yogurt was borderline gross.  The granola, though, was great, with a nice chewy texture.On the whole, I'm indifferent to Le Pain Quotidien.  It's average food, and it isn't particularly cheap.  On the other hand, it's quick and conveniently located for a pre-travel nosh, so I suppose it's adequate for the purpose it was built to serve.

l2WAmlxbk1t8y1z6yHVrZw.text: I love the decor and cosiness of Le Pain Quotidien (all its branches). In addition to that the place makes me that I'm having a good healthy meal, no matter what I orderI tried their coffee, Cheese platter, and scrambled eggs and other things too. The coffee is actually very good, the rest is Average. so If you are for the coffee, I think you will be very satisfied. but be careful not to rise your bar of expectation about the rest of the food. Though some family and friends love the food there too, but for me it's an okay food to have every once in a while.      The only thing I would suggest for you while there is to try the different spreads they put in the tables, they are something!

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

rmTQ_ba2Q7TCGw8EOgHn5w.text: I really liked this place! It was close by to our hotel and in the train station so that was a plus. They had a great selection and breakfast lasted until 12 or 1230 which was great because we left our hotel later than usual and most places stopped at 11. We usually ate outside of the actual restaurant and the service seemed slower, did not bother as much as regular table service might have been on the inside. Which I did not mind, it seemed super stuffy inside also. Our waiter was very helpful in helping me chose my dish. The teapot is way worth it, it is four dollars American, but it fills up two whole cups for two people, and besides they did not even sell tea by the cup. I really recommend the scones, they give you two and they have out preserves and a chocolate sauce on the tables and they give you clotted cream. Definitely a must if you are in the area or are waiting for you tube or train!

sj8OsLFSMxjiM2geuOrxnw.text: This is where we go when we need to talk after church for Sunday Brunch, to enjoy a coffee or a salad. Service is usually good, food is excellent, although check whether the dressings on the tofu salad are in fact properly vegan - they seem to have elastic concepts for their labelling.Communal table allows for great conversations with neighbours, and really nice coffee.

m8I25inbgY2l84v7xbYtLQ.text: On our recent Eurostar trip to Paris, this was a nice spot for some breakfast before we got onto the train. After a trip to the first floor for some photos with the Eurostar trains (and noting the champagne was closed), we were swiftly seated by the staff.I was impressed by the speed of service despite there being a busy breakfast crowd. The menu consisted mainly of French continental breakfast items, a good introduction to the real thing is a few hours. They did stand up well to scrutiny and were aided by some lovely organic jams.They also serve more substantial meals for later in the day but the breakfast bore good comparison with similar offering in Paris.

uS5uGH9PRFE-9X5oWa1Hhw.text: Superb place for coffee and a cake.  Nice surroundings in kensington.

5hxx8Qiz5qgcKlwoHTomaQ.text: One of my favourite branches of this chain. Service is great, and especially friendly if you're a regular. Nice big tables where you can spread out and get some work done if you feel like it, or just have a coffee and a bite to eat. Interior is really nicely done too - brick walls with industrial ceilings. I find the mains a little pricey, but it's great for breakfast - two huge slices of their delicious bread with as much jam/marmalade/chocolate spread as you can handle!

-E1NeQrBnmB1OGZZgMIlqg.text: "What is this and why is it in my mouth?" Those were the words spoken by my husband as he pulled a mashed sticker out of his mouth; the sticker had accidentally been adhered to the bread instead of the wrapper, leading to a chewy surprise.Other than the sticker incident, I liked my experience here. The ham and gruyiere baguette was a perfect sandwich to bring aboard the train for a "travel" lunch.

bfLZsuaWVRE3govykIXd3A.text: Given the location, this charming, rustic themed cafe is usually bustling with city commuters and European travelers looking for a respite before venturing out into London. Staff are friendly, and typically efficient given the locale, with prices equally befitting the surroundings. You do get what you pay for however- a very distinguishing factor for this cafe is the working, no registration needed wifi. its the simple things that matter...

5tYf-JL0QigxMQK_sXAB3g.text: Good food. Bad service.  Great atmosphere.  The waiter actually disputed what I had ordered when the wrong food came out.  Really.  I knew what I ordered. But the food was nice.

A1B6AVeGTIAmUxmw4nQw6w.text: All I know is that when I was starving and rushing through St. Pancras for the Eurostar, Le Pain Quotidien came to my rescue with a delicious spinach and ricotta puff pastry. I wish we had had more time to wander around and look at the menu, because it looked really cute on the outside and in, but oh well. I love bakeries and especially bread (maybe just carbs in general?) so this would definitely be on my hit list should I ever pass through the UK and stumble upon this again.

BtU3qV2darGw4QWIQfj7wA.text: Hot chocolate, white chocolate spread on the freshest chewiest crustiest bread, fast service, communal tables, happy kids  what better way to start a journey?

E2L_Zc8S_y-OE7WdsvrLkw.text: I used to live in Brussels and le pain quotidien was one of my favourite places for brunch, so I was over the moon when I saw it had also arrived in London. When it comes to brunch, it would be pretty hard to beat the french cakes and sandwiches on offer here - from the croissants to the big bowls of cafe latte to the chocolate bombe cake which is soo chocolately it gives you a headache - this is a perfect little place to head for a pick me up after shopping, to grab a snack on the way somewhere, or just to sit one of the huge tables and meet new people

J7te9qjrTq_F-sa7hI5fMQ.text: I've been to Le Pain Quotidien at St Pancras twice now: once after a trip on Eurostar and once on getting off the train from Luton, both times when I was hungry but knew that the fridge at home needed filling. The bread is fabulous, just as it should be given that the translation of the name is 'daily bread'. I've thoroughly enjoyed both the Mediterranean and Smoked Salmon Platters, although the addition of sheets of seaweed to the latter was, in my opinion, completely unnecessary and confusing to the overall taste. If you like what you eat, you can always pop next door to the Pain Quotidien shop, where they sell their breads, condiments and cakes, although £16.00 for 2 loaves and 4 little tarts seemed a bit pricey to us. Still, the convenience of knowing that this place will feed you healthy, fresh food if, like us, you've been travelling and would like to be fed before tackling chores such as filling the fridge, is much appreciated by this Qyper, as are the friendly staff and efficient service.

dV67dmNC_J-tBO22Nc-j_g.text: Great election of sandwiches, quiche, beverages and baked goods. The packaging is very nice and keeps food fresh but is easy to open. As close to an authentic French sandwich shop as you're likely to come in contact with as a last stop from London to the Continent via boarding Eurostar (train food is ££££ and not very good). Definitely on the top five best boulangerie chains I've been to.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Yummy sandwiches.
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

7bwywRlebMWBfmztP6oZRw.text: I have a love/hate relationship with this place. I regularly stop here on my way to work when I change at St Pancras and want something healthy for breakfast. It is ALWAYS busy during rush hour but you can usually find a seat even if it's at the back of the restaurant which is fine. The food is great, always fresh and usually comes pretty quickly. I just have an issue with the service. I've waited at the door to be seated for 10 minutes before whilst staff chat to each other, clear tables etc. Surely you want to get people seated asap when there's space!? It's not a one off either, the lack of service happens all the time and I had a firm word about it once when I waited 15 minutes at the door and had staff constantly walk past me and half the restaurant was empty. The host shouted at me 'what do you expect we're busy can't you see that', which horrified me. I'm a pretty patient person but I just don't do bad service when it's completely unnecessary. Like a fool I keep coming back but as long as I ask for the bill straight away when my food arrives then I don't have to wait forever for somebody to bring it to me at the end and I'm away relatively quickly. I'd definitely give this place a 4/5 star though if the service was better.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Avocado on toast
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Scrambled eggs and avocado
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Green tea

8WOSxhdmxjq77o287y3XsQ.text: I heard of Le Pain Quotidien for AGES when i used to live in Paris. It's a big thing there and in Belgium. So when i went to St Pancras to welcome my brother out of the Eurostar i thought i might try it (didn't even know it existed in London before that day).The place is quite big and i appreciated the looks of it. The staff was warm and welcoming. We were placed as we saw fitted (not next to the window, i hate these seats) and my brother's luggages were taken in some convenient place so it wouldn't be a danger for anyone to stumble upon. We both ordered the breakfast menu (croissant/pain au chocolat, assorted breads, jam and chocolate spread, hot beverage, small orange juice) with avocado as an extra.Well i was disappointed. For a total of £21, i expected better. Extra avocado is £1.95 for half of it. The croissant was ok but not fresh (it was 9:30) and my brother couldn't even eat is pain au chocolat because he didn't like it. The breads were good and the chocolate spread really good though (better than nutella i'd swear). Our coffees weren't hot when served so it turned cold real fast and i could finish it. The orange juice seemed fresh and was good. I expected this first experience to be way better. I would not go back as i know where to find better breakfasts for less money anywhere else in London. At your own risks.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

CFAxYbaVht1D6JQDq13Fwg.text: St Pancras Station has a weird mix of high end shops and then high-street eateries. I've only once had a meal in at LPQ as it's all a bit, well, Belgian for my liking. However, I am a fan of the to-go section to the right of the restaurant.I'm a bit of an almond croissant aficionado, and the ones at LPQ are my favourite in the whole station. Fresh and light and gooey and delicious. What keeps the review at 3 stars is that the rest of the offerings there are pretty standard and in line with other places in the station but at a higher price. The staff are usually friendly and polite, but they're never in any sort of rush (and as I'm always running late in the morning, it's a bit frustrating!).

TOkLFtM0QpLEx6vad1EZvw.text: My wife and I loved the food and service and I  would definitely recommend them to friends and family.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. This was so delicious and tasty!

v0StJRB_uFo3Y9mzM5PeTA.text: Where can i start, i am a big fan of PQ . I like their soups, Salads ( fav) and tarts, cheese cake and machato (omio dio). Fantastic experience

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Heart breaker

OU6snrQQp2XclrHfA4hohQ.text: Get that rude French service before leaving for Paris. I can understand slow ... check that ... NO service at a snooty Paris Bistro, but at a train station where people are in a hurry?!? Gobsmacked doesn't even BEGIN to cover it.

xhFCXeiqVMn7qjrJrYbl8g.text: Stumbled out of my hotel in need of sustenance for the afternoon.  I sat outsdie and ordered 2 soft boiled eggs Sparkling water1 MacchiatoAnd people watched all the bustling shoppers and travelers and tourists and locals. Service was prompt (promptly European that is) and kind. A piano player was just down the way serenading everyone.  Over all: great food, good service and lovely atmosphere.

4VDGfFRQLWTrvNYKrkw7Rw.text: When in Rome.....love this place but they do not "get" English tea ( the drink)...everything else perfect but if in London they need to serve a reasonable cuppa.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

D_nvf22VP7Tn6oHxc7g8rw.text: Food for me was a little lacklustre, BUT.... Service was excellent, despite being very very busy. Smily, friendly, attentive. Got us everything we needed in record time. Big thumbs up. Atmosphere is good - it's one of the busiest spots in Pancras, it's warm and cosy and actually right opposite the Eurostar entrance so quite well positioned for a quick bite. Even though it's table service, you can be in and out of here within 20 minutes. Like I mentioned above, food for me was under par - we had two salads. The nicest thing about them was the bread that came with it. Perhaps having a salad in a chain that's actually called "the daily bread" isn't a good shout. So yeah, stick with the breaded goods.

ZR_XWKHJt8kJJPf7NAGbkA.text: Exemplary service and top notch breads, pastries, and other dishesOur family of four breakfasted here before our Eurostar trip to France. Even though the restaurant was completely packed the service was exemplary - polite, quick, and efficient. The food was delicious with our party enjoying a variety of Le Pain's egg and pastry dishes and the coffee and chocolate beverages were wonderful as well. In fact the only off-note was the Earl Grey tea which was really rather awful - particularly for London. In short, Le Pain is a great choice for a quick bite at St Pancras while waiting for your train.

pXYHfJ6VJMJzJX0vNHB5-g.text: Great place for a Breakie or more. No surprise here, same menu as in the other Pain Quotidien, that's why I'm here too. Service is good, people are nice, classical music playing in the morning for a slow waking up ...

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Squeezed juice with soy milk oatmeal with berries and lindsee seeds
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. They open really early, at 5pm! Pretty cool to wait for the 1st train back to Paris.

JP8H2HZFjiPwyODrJaMDWA.text: I visit this place when staying in a nearby hotel just because it's a nostalgic throw back to my times in NYC & New Jersey. Yes it's a big corporate but it's open late for me and it's in the wonder that is St Pancras. That's two pluses right there.They do great lunch/brunch/breakfast fixes too and although thy get busy, tables are turned quickly, mindful of the fact that most customers will be in a rush to get a train.It's a shame they don't offer the same sweet chai they do in the US but they do have the lovely service here.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Devon tart
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Scrambled eggs w/ salmon
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Wow, gorgeous colours, limeade &  raspberry lemonade

-8ADnacSLSXhxfFLVyW5VA.text: Staff were decent and the food was OK, but I think £6 for a small amount of scrambled eggs on a few slivers of bread was a bit of a joke.  This, combined with some baby roast potatoes and a raspberry tart came to £15 without a tip.  Decent food but not worth it in my opinion.

PtQ9L9L_FA_6QUuK9ElVBA.text: Great scrambled eggs and pastries. My cappuccino was good too. I suggest coming here before your train

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Scrambled eggs with toast
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Granola parfait
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Praline Danish!

psFIiO_CBkj2M6DFs3Mu9A.text: We have tried most of their baked goods and are happy to say their Almond Croissant is one of the best you can get in London.  We also like their Walnut Sourdough Bread which has the lovely chewy texture & sourdough taste and is packed with walnuts.  Rye bread is very sour and has a strong flavour; so it is an acquired taste.  Tarte au Citron is OK; I think they just put lemon curd in pre-baked tart case rather than using the proper lemon/butter/egg/cream filling and bake it.

XHlNxUiELPotHOyqd1Os0A.text: Quick, good and efficient. Exactly what you want before catching your train to Paris or Brussels.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Tasty hot chocolate.
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Looks tasty!

fCY_07O6XDOqyrKhtujJLA.text: It's a fun place to meet friends for a light breakfast or afternoon tea, but not the quintessential British experience. If you are looking for something a bit more English, walk down a bit further to Fortnum & Mason for some tea.It's a great way to ease into the French lifestyle if you are travelling to Paris on the Eurostar. Good selection of teas and coffees. It will get your tastebuds alive, ready for your Parisienne trip at 300km/h.It gets a bit noisy, especially outside in the main station, and it can be a bit disorientating because of all the glass and the two entrances. Once you get past that you'll be fine. Enjoy.

P9CiO1dFbwvicC8LZBnnXQ.text: Ideally located right outside the exit of the Eurostar, this is the place to come to if you feel like a delicious breakfast or a light lunch. The wooden decor gives a cosy feeling to the place. The menu offers a large selection of breakfast options. You can share a basket of various breads and try out their numerous spreads : apricot jam, marmalade, speculoos spread or even white or dark chocolate flavours. You can also order the usual French croissant or a soft-boiled egg. If you are after a light lunch, they serve some delicious soups and tartines with bacon, chicken and all sorts of veggies. You might have to queue for a few minutes as the place is quite popular but they usually serve relatively quickly. They also have large tables if you come with a group, which is quite convenient. There is still enough space around if you do not feel like interacting with your neighbour. If you are in a hurry, you can also buy a croissant, pastry or a sandwich at their store next door.

NW2vl4MwfpQt-eSjsu97aA.text: I'm a big fan of Le Pain Quotidien. I have been to the orignal one in Brussels, and this one in St Pancras is just as good. The selection of food is great, and has something for everyone and every craving. I had the gluten free muesli and soy milk. The portion sizes are plentiful. The service is fast and efficient.I would definitely recommend going here before jumping on the Eurostar to Brussels or Pairs!

TGRfSNk_6teJ64N-uxxlGQ.text: I really enjoyed my time in here.Despite it being superbly busy, it's literally in kings cross station. Full of tourists and bags, which normally means I'm out. It was early on a Sunday and needed a breakfast. This was the clear winner looking at the menu so I headed in.Server was really helpful, I had the full Belgian, water and a glass of prosecco.The bread was the clear star of the show here. A sort of muffin type thing. Wonderful - perfectly salted and with a little butter, was the best.The ham was crispy and had a wonderfully smoked taste, the eggs done to perfection - and the tomatoes, the things I normally avoid on a breakfast, were even great.Service was quick, a low optional service charge and a nice atmosphere.If I find myself nearby and in need again, I'll certainly be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

CYZe_--a0Wqp7FspfZ8lUQ.text: We came here most mornings to start our day and plan out the rest of our day.Great selection of pastries and eggy meals. I usually got a pain au chocolate and a mint tea.The service was usually spot on and there were tons of travelers coming in and out of this spot in Kings Cross.If you some of the best people watching, sit outside and watch all the travelers come and go.

2z6Y73un0T51Zt02xBr6Iw.text: 4 stars - this place really hit the spot after traveling for a couple of hours. We were all pretty hungry after getting off the train from Paris to London and this place just happen to be at the train station. We decided to stop in and get a real breakfast/brunch, and it was just perfect. I ordered a cup of chai tea and the scrambled eggs, avocado toast and salmon on toast. This restaurant also has family style seating with long wooden tables and chairs. It almost feel like we were sitting in the kitchen. Another perk was there was various jams and jellies available in each table to use on your croissant or bread. There was also a white chocolate spread, that so good (even for breakfast). I also found there are other Le Pain Quotidian's around London and also some in NYC, if you are in the US. It was a pleasant experience and I hope to come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Hot pot of tea
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Beverage menu
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Chalkboard art

LrEOOFcqoUy5Senedh5NVg.text: Great location and atmosphere, but the coffee simply did not have a good taste. Almond croissant was good, but not good enough to make up for the poor coffee.

-IWTfS40gWCWsq15UoVBHw.text: A latte (mid size) for £3.1, not even including the service charge, really?It's definitely a decent place but truly expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Prices as of December 3rd 2017

NS71LBgX4sV3nQ592NF7Ew.text: I tried this place twice once for breakfast and once for launch.They didn't disappoint me.I love the service.They are fast and clean.I love the quinoa salad with avocado on side.A little pricy but you have to remember you are eating at a train station.I will try them again when I am back in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

C46w-5a-FcXzr-o9Zk0bmA.text: Sit-down dining inside St. Pancras station. Not super fast, though, if you have a train to catch.We had a train out of King's Cross but hopped over to St. Pancras to see their food options, which are upscale but less grab-and-go. Le Pain Quotidien is a global chain, so this is probably the third or fourth location I've visited. Prices are higher, but the food quality is also higher. The interior design is homely, clean, lots of bare wood, and some long communal dining tables. We walked in and were seated immediately. The menu is focused and not too extensive. I went with a roasted vegetable salad and wife did the smoked salmon tartine. Everything was delicious, fresh ingredients, and the portions were pretty sizeable. Service was solid. Overall, very nice while waiting for the Eurostar or if you want something upscale coming from King's Cross.

WBmRg1ux1mpxx9lImiviTg.text: Very good food and good service. Thomas was very helpful as was the rest of the staff. We had soup and avocado toast.

VQmcokv4fkDpF6-brRy40g.text: If you're wandering about St Pancras have brunch or lunch here. It's always yummy with something for everyone.

B9fe8m6sQNr49lFOkgJtRA.text: I came here because I was catching the train to France. The food here is fabulous. I tried many things and they were all good. You can't order anything that's not good here..

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

MD-g-7qCvCo0jmMpW5xI9Q.text: Stopped in for a quick bite to eat before heading to Paris.  Service was awesome, food was phenomenal! I had the avocado toast and scrambled eggs, both met my expectations!

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

P8HCKdplHG6vkh2WKz1oMA.text: Not great. The food was sort of bad, but maybe I had weird expectations. Not sure. The service was okay.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

OULBcS9VMVWLFdHWGy2qzg.text: Amazing place at beautiful at St. Pancras train station. Typical French patisserie with high quality food and well organized service! Crowded, which is the best proof of performance. Went there for breakfast with omelette, croissant and soft boiled eggs. Not forgetting about amazing large cappuccino served in a soup bowl. We felt immediately like jumping on Eurostar to Paris :-D

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Large !!!

QrpGS_wYwmuYxVC3O4rMKQ.text: Slow grumpy service from (likely overwhelmed) staff.  Mediocre coffee.  Almond croissant was the highlight- flaky with right amount of paste.

11NiRVjwbwQWgM148jZoeA.text: My go to place before jumping on the train for a hearty and healthy breakfast/brunch. They have a seasonal menu with great Organic and superfood choice. Everything is fresh and the service is courteous and quick.Get the avocado toast and try their different spread (the speculoos one is my favourite)

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast before boarding the eurostar

C8T4xIof-XtLR8cqGcezag.text: I thought this was a cute little place in the train station. You have to get the pastries and breads yourself. We had the little cheese baguette log and it was really good.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Cheese baguette

-a0S2ZZo3ruLKtdpM_W89g.text: Although this was quite busy when I went (even for 7 in the morning), the service was good and our waiter was attentive. I had a quiche, bread and mixed greens salad breakfast dish. The quiche was savory, soft and came with a topping of asparagus and cheese, which gave it good texture and bite. The salad was crisp and refreshing, and the bread was great-quality and hearty.Overall, it's a good place for a quality breakfast or brunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom

RNrMM8JiEaN_3_KJOfsimQ.text: I love "Le pain quotidien" ! It reminds me of my country :-) This one is often quite busy because it's located in the middle of St Pancras Station. Before taking my Eurostar to Brussels, I usually end up at Le Pain Quotidien "just for sandwiches to go". I LOVE their mozzarella tomato and avocado one. And also the chicken, spring onion and tomato one.I also usually go out with a hot drink (they have almond milk and matcha latte ! What else ?), a pastry and my sandwiches (the "official" goal of me coming in, remember?). It's also a great place to wait for friends and family :) with a fresh mint tea or a hot chocolate or a matcha latte. And some tartines. Well, I love this place :-)

FDfnVRipkCVsm0p1NRrWSQ.text: This was truly diaappointing. Staff were largely disengaged...they were definitely not attentive enough; got a few requests wrong and had to ask a few times to get some water. The waitress carried on checking through the orders despite the fact that I was coughing to death and was clearly in need of some water quickly.The portion sizes were also disappointing and the food was mediocre. I used to think this was a nice place to go but I wouldn't recommend it.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Matcha latte yum
Photo of Le Pain Quotidien - London, United Kingdom. Salmon and scrambled eggs

AgJDVYuu3prbvPF-WpE5DQ.text: It's right across from the entrance for Eurostar and they will dependably deliver some good morning (or afternoon) grub + good people watching, so you don't have to worry about getting to Saint Pancras early - you can just go here.
